column1: publish_date;headline_text
20231220;"The UK Supreme Court has upheld earlier decisions in rejecting a bid to allow an artificial intelligence to be named as an inventor in a patent application.
Technologist Dr Stephen Thaler had sought to have his AI
column2: called Dabus
column3: recognised as the inventor of a food container and a flashing light beacon.

column1: But in 2019
column2: the intellectual property office (IPO) rejected this
column3: saying only a person could be named as an inventor.

column1: The decision was then backed by both the High Court and Court of Appeal.
The IPO has argued
column2: and courts have supported the view
column3: that only ""persons"" can have patent rights

column1: Now five Supreme Court judges have dismissed a bid to reverse those decisions
column2: concluding that ""an inventor must be a person""
column3: and that an AI cannot be named as an inventor to secure patent rights.

column1: The judgement does not deal with the issue of whether Dabus did in fact invent the food container and light.
Dr Thaler
column2: who believes that Dabus is a ""conscious and sentient form of machine intelligence""
column4: I feel disappointed by this decision
column5: highlighting the ongoing clash between human and machine intelligence.""

column1: The IPO told the BBC it welcomed the judgement and the clarification it provided.
But it added that ""the government will nevertheless keep this area of law under review to ensure that the UK patent system supports AI innovation and the use of AI in the UK"".
Rajvinder Jagdev
column2: of specialist intellectual property litigation firm Powell Gilbert
column3: said: ""The judgement does not preclude a person using an AI to devise an invention - in such a scenario
column4: it would be possible to apply for a patent
column5: provided that person is identified as the inventor. The judgement alludes that had this been the scenario it had been asked to consider
column6: the outcome may have been different.""

column1: Legitimate questions
Dr Thaler also argued that he was entitled to patents for Dabus inventions as the AI's owner
column2: but this was rejected.

column1: A different decision could have caused ""headaches for companies using [AI] software to innovate as they may not be the owner of the patent""
column2: Diego Black
column3: from European intellectual property firm Withers and Rogers

column1: Simon Barker
column2: of law firm Freeths
column3: said the judgement raised ""interesting policy questions"" about how governments might look to change laws in the future as AI advances.

column1: There are similar debates in other areas of intellectual property rights too. Copyright in AI-generated works
column2: for example. Is the programmer of the AI the creator
column3: or the user who is responsible for prompting the machine? And what if it really is just the machine itself
column4: like Dr Thaler claimed of Dabus?""

column1: But Professor Ryan Abbott of the University of Surrey who represented Dr Thaler in the case said the decision implied that ""AI
column2: at best
column3: can be a 'highly sophisticated tool' that can be used by people who invent.

column1: This affects the meaning of an ""inventor"" under UK patent law
column2: and to be an inventor
column3: one need not make the creative leap behind the invention
column4: as had been previously assumed. Accordingly
column5: companies who use AI to develop products will have to say they or their employees are the inventors
column6: even when the humans involved do little else but switch on the computer.""

column1: Some legal experts expect pressure for changes to existing laws to grow
column2: as AIs become increasingly capable of autonomously generating novel ideas.

column1: In its statement
column2: the IPO said it recognised ""that there are legitimate questions as to how the patent system and indeed intellectual property more broadly should handle [AI] creations"".

column1: In June 2022
column2: the UK government published a response to its consultation on AI and intellectual property.

column1: The response concluded that there should be no legal change to UK patent law now
column2: and noted that many share the view that any future change would need to be at an international level. The decision of the Supreme Court does not alter that conclusion

column1: 20240223;"Nvidia's market value has touched $2tn (£1.58tn)
column2: a new milestone in the chipmaker's rapid ascent into the ranks of the world's most valuable companies.

column1: Shares in the Silicon Valley firm rose more than 4% in morning trade on Friday before dropping back a bit.
The gains extended a jump after the company's blockbuster earnings report this week.
The company is benefiting from advances in artificial intelligence (AI)
column2: which have powered demand for its chips.

column1: Turnover at the firm more than doubled last year to more than $60bn
column2: and boss Jensen Huang told investors this week that demand was ""surging"" around the world.

column1: The company
column2: which became worth $1tn less than a year ago
column3: now ranks as the world's fourth most valuable publicly traded company

column1: After shares retreated from their early Friday highs
column2: the firm's market value ended the day just below $2tn.

column1: Founded in 1993
column2: Nvidia was originally known for making the type of computer chips that process graphics

column1: Long before the AI revolution
column2: it started adding features to its chips that it says help machine learning
column3: investments that have helped it gain market share.

column1: It is now seen as a key company to watch to see how fast AI-powered tech is spreading across the business world.
The price of the firm's shares has more than tripled over the last 12 months
column2: from less than $240 apiece to nearly $800 in mid-day trade on Friday.

column1: On Thursday
column2: the day after its earnings report
column3: buyers snapping up shares pushed its value up by $277bn
column4: Wall Street's largest one-day gain in history.

column1: The report has also helped to drive a broader market rally
column2: appearing to convince investors that
column3: as Derren Nathan of Hargreaves Lansdown put it
column4: the boom in AI was ""living up to the hype"".

column1: It's being used in automotive for design
column2: it's being used in telecommunications for planning networks
column3: it's being used in mainstream companies to figure out and get insights into data that they haven't been able to get before
column5: a US-based technology analyst told the BBC earlier this week.

column1: This is now really starting to hit the kinds of companies across the board
column2: not just specialised tech companies and that's a real tipping point for the industry."""
